objects.name: Recording targeted applications for one-time password
break the newest methods of OTP
start the accessibility settings activity, coercing the user to grant it with accessibility permissions
Preventing the user from uninstalling the app
Becoming the default SMS app by changing device settings
uses accessibility services to identify and control some of these screens and make its own choices before giving the user a chance to react
uses the AlarmManager to set a pending intent that will run its own service after a predefined interval
uses the shared preferences mechanism to store settings and data that the malware uses at runtime
uses an obfuscator to scramble the names of its functions, classes and variables
checks if the app is running on a rooted device or an emulator to prevent analysis
steal all SMS messages that are stored on the device
sends a packet to its C&C server containing the collected device data along with all the saved SMS messages
delete the SMS messages so only the attackers can see them
automatic mechanism to send SMS messages to its C&C server
send log data of important actions
save an SMS message on the device, marking with “internal” in the phone number field
SMS message will be instantly sent to the server, informing the malware operator of executed tasks
blocks the user’s access to their banking website after a successful transaction by using web injects that show a variety of “service unavailable” screens
activating the lock screen and preventing the user from accessing their device
record the screen when targeted apps are running
capture a video of the screen when the targeted application is presented
Using the accessibility service to save a text file containing the data of all the objects on the screen
displays a query for the mobile phone number and the device type used for banking and then prompts users to install an alleged security app
“kill switch” that can eliminate the malware remotely
impersonating their bank with web injections, fools the victim into installing a fake security app
see a web injection asking for their mobile device operating system (OS) type and phone number.
overcome the newer pushTAN app validations deployed by banks
using web injects that tricked users into downloading a mobile component called “ZitMo”
intercepting the SMS messages coming from the bank
stealing the mTANs without the victim’s knowledge
bypass second factor and strong authentication pushed to bank customers when they need to authorize a transaction
steal transaction authorization codes from victims who download the app
uses man-in-the-browser (MITB) web injects in online banking sessions to ask infected users for their mobile phone number and device type
“kill switch” that can remotely eliminate the malware
steal TANs using screen video recording and screen data scraping
avoid user interaction by running in the background as a service
service will start either after the device becomes interactive or after a new SMS message is received
connects to its designated server via an unencrypted HTTP request
sends over a JSON object that contains data gleaned from the victim’s phone
Send AES-encrypted SMS message back to sender
Update the address of the C&C server
Update the address of the C&C server
Display a picture in a WebView from an arbitrary URL
Use the accessibility service to become the default SMS app
Steal images saved on the device
lockdown screen persists after a restart and is re-initiated every time the device becomes interactive
turn on the kill switch and initiate its own removal
